questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is/are correct.
question_texts: Which of the following statements is/are correct.

options.option_text: SMTP is a mail delivery protocol.
SMTP is a protocol to retrieve email from an email server.
IMAP is a mail delivery protocol.
IMAP is a protocol to retrieve email from an email server.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are correct regarding CDN.
question_texts: Which of the following is/are correct regarding CDN.

options.option_text: CDN is an acronym for Content Delivery Network.
CDN is a group of servers that helps in fast delivery of web contents.
Web content is generally delivered from the closest server to the client in thenetwork.

options.option_text: A webhook uses web socket protocol.
A webhook receiver must be deployed on the same origin as the webhookinitiator.

XSS can be used to steal the user's cookie.

questions.question_text_1: You are trying to build a distributed system with N servers, each of which may need to communicate with any of the other servers. Which of the following statement(s) is/are true?
question_texts: You are trying to build a distributed system with N servers, each of which may need to communicate with any of the other servers. Which of the following statement(s) is/are true?

options.option_text: With point-to-point communication, the number of connection links will growas O(n).
With point-to-point communication, the number of connection links will growas O(n2).
With the use of a central message broker, the number of connection links willgrow as O(n).
With the use of a central message broker, the number of connection links willgrow as O(n2).

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding long and short polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding long and short polling?

options.option_text: A webhook is the same as short polling.
The short polling can be used to know the state of an asynchronous task, andtrigger an action if the task gets completed.
The long polling cannot be achieved using HTTP protocol.
Long Polling can be used to achieve real time communication.

options.option_text: It is recommended to cache the social networking apps feed responses for alonger duration.
Caching is primarily done to reduce the load from the origin server.
The shared cache is meant to serve responses to the multiple users.
A browser cannot cache JavaScript corresponding to a web page.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **"Modern Application Development II"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ## **1. Core Topics & Concepts** ### **A. Web Protocols & Communication** #### **1. Email Protocols** - **SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol)** - Used for **sending/mail delivery** (not retrieval). - Port: `25` (unencrypted), `587` (TLS). - **IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol)** - Used for **retrieving emails** from a server. - Supports **server-side folders**, synchronization. - Port: `143` (unencrypted), `993` (SSL/TLS). - **POP3 (Post Office Protocol 3)** - Retrieves emails but **deletes them from the server** by default. #### **2. HTTP/HTTPS & APIs** - **REST APIs**: Stateless, uses HTTP methods (`GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`). - **WebSockets**: Full-duplex communication over a single TCP connection. - **Webhooks**: **Machine-to-machine** communication via HTTP callbacks (not WebSockets). - Example: GitHub webhooks for CI/CD triggers. #### **3. CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)** - **Same-Origin Policy**: Blocks requests to different **scheme (HTTP/HTTPS)**, **host (domain)**, or **port**. - **CORS Headers**: - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`: Specifies allowed origins. - `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`: Allowed HTTP methods. - **Preflight Request**: `OPTIONS` request sent before actual request for non-simple requests. #### **4. CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)** - **Attack**: Tricks users into submitting malicious requests (e.g., deleting an account) via authenticated sessions. - **Mitigation**: - **CSRF Tokens**: Unique tokens per session. - **SameSite Cookies**: Restrict cookie sending to same-site requests. #### **5. XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)** - **Types**: - **Stored XSS**: Malicious script stored on the server (e.g., in a database). - **Reflected XSS**: Script reflected in response (e.g., via URL parameters). - **DOM-based XSS**: Script executes in the browser due to DOM manipulation. - **Mitigation**: - Input validation/sanitization. - Use `Content Security Policy (CSP)` headers. --- ### **B. JavaScript & Frontend Frameworks** #### **1. JavaScript Core Concepts** - **First-Class Functions**: Functions treated as variables (can be passed as arguments). - **Higher-Order Functions**: Functions that take/return other functions (e.g., `map`, `filter`). - **Closures**: Inner functions retain access to outer function variables. - **Asynchronous JS**: - **Callbacks**: Function passed as an argument to be executed later. - **Promises**: `.then()`/`.catch()` for async operations. - **Async/Await**: Syntactic sugar for promises. - **Event Loop**: Handles async operations (call stack, callback queue, microtask queue). #### **2. DOM Manipulation** - **Methods**: - `document.getElementById()` - `element.addEventListener()` - `element.innerHTML` - **Virtual DOM (Vue/React)**: Efficient updates by comparing virtual and real DOM. #### **3. Vue.js** - **Directives**: - `v-for`: Loop over arrays/objects. ```html
``` - `v-model`: Two-way data binding. - `v-bind`: Bind attributes (`:class`, `:style`). - `v-on`: Event handling (`@click`). - **Components**: - **Props**: Pass data from parent to child. - **Slots**: Distribute content (``). - **Scoped Slots**: Pass data from child to parent. - **Vuex (State Management)**: - **State**: Single source of truth. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state updates. - **Actions**: Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - **Getters**: Computed properties for state. - **Vue Router**: Client-side routing (``). - **Reactivity**: Automatic UI updates when data changes. #### **4. AJAX & Real-Time Communication** - **Polling**: - **Short Polling**: Client requests server at fixed intervals. - **Long Polling**: Server holds request until new data is available. - **Server-Sent Events (SSE)**: One-way server-to-client updates. - **WebSockets**: Full-duplex communication (e.g., chat apps). --- ### **C. Backend & Distributed Systems** #### **1. Flask (Python)** - **Caching**: - **Redis**: In-memory cache (used with `Flask-Caching`). - **Cache Headers**: `Cache-Control`, `ETag`. - **Route Handling**: ```python @app.route('/') @cache.cached(timeout=120) # Cache for 120 seconds def home(): return "Hello World" ``` #### **2. Distributed Systems** - **Point-to-Point Communication**: - **Complexity**: `O(n²)` connections (each node connects to every other node). - **Central Message Broker (e.g., RabbitMQ, Kafka)**: - **Complexity**: `O(n)` connections (each node connects to the broker). - **CDN (Content Delivery Network)**: - **Purpose**: Reduce latency by serving content from edge servers. - **How it works**: - User requests content → CDN routes to nearest edge server. - If content is cached, it’s served immediately; else, fetched from origin. #### **3. Celery (Task Queue)** - **Components**: - **Broker**: Message queue (Redis, RabbitMQ). - **Workers**: Execute tasks. - **Result Backend**: Store task results (optional). - **Features**: - Asynchronous task execution. - Periodic tasks (`Celery Beat`). --- ### **D. Security** | **Attack** | **Description** | **Mitigation** | |------------------|------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------| | **XSS** | Inject malicious scripts. | Input sanitization, CSP headers. | | **CSRF** | Trick users into submitting requests. | CSRF tokens, SameSite cookies. | | **CORS Misconfig** | Overly permissive CORS headers. | Restrict `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`. | | **SQL Injection** | Inject SQL queries. | Use ORM/parameterized queries. | --- ### **E. Caching** - **Types**: - **Browser Cache**: Stores static assets (HTML, CSS, JS). - **CDN Cache**: Caches content at edge locations. - **Server Cache**: Redis, Memcached. - **Shared Cache**: Caches responses for multiple users (e.g., CDN). - **Cache Invalidation**: Strategies to update cached data (TTL, manual purge). --- ### **F. Algorithms & Data Structures (JS Context)** - **Closures & `this` Binding**: - `var` vs. `let`/`const` in loops (e.g., `setTimeout` with `var` leaks `i`). - **Promise Chaining**: - `.then()` executes after promise resolves. - `.catch()` handles rejections. - **Event Loop**: - Microtasks (Promises) > Macrotasks (setTimeout, I/O). --- --- ## **2. Key Equations & Code Snippets** ### **A. JavaScript** #### **1. Closure in Loops** ```javascript for (var i = 0; i < 3; i++) { setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1000); // Output: 3, 3, 3 } ``` **Fix**: Use `let` or IIFE. ```javascript for (let i = 0; i < 3; i++) { setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1000); // Output: 0, 1, 2 } ``` #### **2. Promise Execution Order** ```javascript console.log("First"); Promise.resolve().then(() => console.log("Second")); console.log("Third"); // Output: First, Third, Second ``` #### **3. Async/Await** ```javascript async function func() { await Promise.resolve(7); console.log("Second"); return 7; } console.log("First"); func().then(data => console.log(data)); console.log("Third"); // Output: First, Third, Second, 7 ``` --- ### **B. Vue.js** #### **1. Vuex Mutation** ```javascript mutations: { belowAverageStudents(state) { state.below_average = state.students.filter(s => s.marks > 50); } } ``` #### **2. Computed Property** ```javascript computed: { amount() { return this.cart.reduce((total, item) => total + item.price * item.count, 0); } } ``` #### **3. Slots** ```html
``` --- ### **C. Flask Caching** ```python from flask_caching import Cache cache = Cache(app, config={'CACHE_TYPE': 'RedisCache'}) @app.route('/') @cache.cached(timeout=120) # Cache for 120 seconds def home(): return "Hello World" ``` --- ### **D. CORS Headers** ```http Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://trusted-site.com Access-Control-Allow-Methods: GET, POST Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Content-Type ``` --- --- ## **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **Graph 1: Web Protocols & Security** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Protocols] --> B[SMTP] A --> C[IMAP] A --> D[HTTP/HTTPS] D --> E[REST APIs] D --> F[WebSockets] D --> G[Webhooks] A --> H[Security] H --> I[XSS] H --> J[CSRF] H --> K[CORS] I --> L[Input Sanitization] J --> M[CSRF Tokens] K --> N[Access-Control-Allow-Origin] ``` ### **Graph 2: JavaScript & Frontend** ```mermaid graph TD A[JavaScript] --> B[Asynchronous] B --> C[Callbacks] B --> D[Promises] B --> E[Async/Await] A --> F[Closures] A --> G[Event Loop] G --> H[Microtasks] G --> I[Macrotasks] A --> J[DOM Manipulation] J --> K[Virtual DOM] A --> L[Vue.js] L --> M[Directives] L --> N[Components] L --> O[Vuex] L --> P[Vue Router] ``` ### **Graph 3: Backend & Distributed Systems** ```mermaid graph TD A[Backend] --> B[Flask] B --> C[Caching] C --> D[Redis] C --> E[Cache Headers] A --> F[Distributed Systems] F --> G[Point-to-Point] F --> H[Message Broker] H --> I[RabbitMQ] H --> J[Kafka] F --> K[CDN] K --> L[Edge Servers] A --> M[Celery] M --> N[Broker] M --> O[Workers] M --> P[Periodic Tasks] ``` ### **Graph 4: Security Attacks & Mitigations** ```mermaid graph TD A[Security Attacks] --> B[XSS] A --> C[CSRF] A --> D[CORS Misconfiguration] B --> E[Stored XSS] B --> F[Reflected XSS] B --> G[DOM-based XSS] E --> H[Sanitize Database Inputs] F --> I[Validate URL Parameters] G --> J[Use CSP Headers] C --> K[Use CSRF Tokens] C --> L[SameSite Cookies] D --> M[Restrict Allow-Origin] ``` ### **Graph 5: Caching Strategies** ```mermaid graph TD A[Caching] --> B[Browser Cache] A --> C[CDN Cache] A --> D[Server Cache] D --> E[Redis] D --> F[Memcached] A --> G[Shared Cache] G --> H[Multi-User Responses] A --> I[Cache Invalidation] I --> J[TTL] I --> K[Manual Purge] ``` --- --- ## **4. Exam Tips** 1. **JavaScript**: - Understand **closures**, **`this` binding**, and **event loop**. - Know how **`var` vs. `let`** behaves in loops. - Practice **promise chaining** and **async/await**. 2. **Vue.js**: - Master **directives** (`v-for`, `v-model`, `v-bind`). - Understand **Vuex** (state, mutations, actions, getters). - Know **slots** (default, named, scoped). 3. **Web Protocols**: - Differentiate **SMTP** (sending) vs. **IMAP** (retrieving). - Understand **CORS** and **CSRF** mitigations. 4. **Backend**: - Know **Flask caching** with Redis. - Understand **Celery** components (broker, workers). 5. **Security**: - Recognize **XSS** (injection) vs. **CSRF** (unauthorized actions). - Know how to set **CSP** and **CORS** headers. 6. **Distributed Systems**: - **Point-to-point**: `O(n²)` connections. - **Message broker**: `O(n)` connections. 7. **Caching**: - Know when to use **browser cache** vs. **CDN cache**. - Understand **cache invalidation** strategies. --- **Good luck!** 🚀 Review the graphs and key concepts thoroughly.
